text: The wall stretches in both directions as far as the eye c see. Barbed wire, armed sentries and guard dogs. This is dividing line. NAPOLEON SOLO crosses no-man’s land, past a sign which re ‘You are now entering East Germany.’ He’s in his 40's, po and confident, with a ready smile. He shows his passport an East German FRONTIER GUARD, addressing him in perfect German. The Guard gestures for him to open his suitcase. Packed a the top are samples of women’s underwear. Solo offers a sample to the Guard, who has a quick look o his shoulder, takes a pair of tights and then hurriedly closes the case, waving Solo through. As Solo leaves the checkpoint, a train is heading towards border as if to cross it, but as it reaches the Berlin Wa the track suddenly curves so that the train remains in th East, running parallel with the Wall. Clearly, a modifica made when the Wall was built.
As Solo walks along we see that he’s being followed. He's aware of it too. Solo enters a bar.

Solo orders a beer. As he drinks, he glances out of the window at the East German SECRET POLICEMAN who is followi him. Next to him, a prim-looking, middle-aged WOMAN finishes h coffee, dabs her lips with the napkin, and leaves. Solo unfolds the lipstick stained napkin. On it is an address, and a message, ‘YOU HAVE COMPETITION.’ Solo puts the napkin in his pocket and exits.

Solo easily loses his tail. He heads to the address on the napkin. Outside is a car, gets in. INT. CAR — DAY The driver, ERNST, is a jovial looking fellow with an air gypsy about him. He flashes a gold-toothed smile at Solo.
If I was a rich man, la la la la.
You're about to be. Here’s your scotch. Solo fetches a bottle of single malt out of his case.
Glendronach 33. How did you find this?
You owe me. That was harder to get through than a pair of jeans.
The jeans as well?? You’re the messiah. Solo produces the jeans.
And you’re greedy, Ernst, but I like you anyway. Now here is an address, and we need to move, the Russians are onto my target. Ernst looks genuinely excited and starts to unbuckle his trousers.
What are you doing Ernst?
I can't wait... He continues his mission. Solo rolls his eyes.
You even got the right size, and I am a little heavier than I used to be.
I predicted that. Did you get me a gun? Ernst pulls his coat off the back seat, only to reveal a large machine gun. SOLO (CONT’D) It’s a machine gun, Ernst. I asked for something discreet.

I am sorry, but it’s the best I could do. The Stasi watch everything. Since the Russians took over, it’s almost impossible to make a dishonest living. Not like when you were in business. Don’t you miss the old black-market days? This hits a nerve with Solo.
What? The hunger, the cold, the filth? Not really, can we go now? I’m in something of a rush.
Ernst points out a dodgy looking automotive repair shop u the arches of the busy railway track.
It’s a chop shop, I used this place for years, but since things have tightened up, there’s not a lot of business here anymore. You want me to wait here?
Yeah, pick me up on the corner, and Ernst, we need to get the girl over the Wall tonight.
It’s all arranged boss.
The walls are covered with motor-racing posters and photographs of famous drivers. Solo approaches a mechanic who is working under a car, we just see a pair of feet.
(in German) I’m looking for Frau Teller. The mechanic rolls out from under the car. Meet GABY TELL a 28 year-old knockout in a boiler suit.

(in German) I'm a little backed up, I won’t be able to get to your car until next week. Gaby affects a hard edge but her clothing, ruffled hair a the oil-smudge on her cheek only serve to accentuate her vulnerability.
(in German) My name is Napoleon Solo. I’m here about your father Frau Teller. Gaby tenses. Solo smiles reassuringly. SOLO (CONT’D) We need your help.
(in English) American? Solo nods.
I haven't seen my father since I was ten years old.
I imagine you're aware of what your father did during the war?
He was the senior scientist in the Nazi rocket program. Is there anything else to know?

After that, he came to work for the U.S. at Los Alamos. Five years ago, he disappeared without a trace. We've been looking for him ever since, but this is the first sign we've had of him. This picture was taken a week ago by one of our agents in Egypt. Solo shows Gaby a black-and-white photograph of half a do men seated at a conference table. Three are wearing high level military uniforms. Solo points to one man who is standing, gesticulating wit his arms as if to make a point. He’s an older professoria type.
That’s him... She can’t hide the emotion in her voice.

It appears your father is in the process of making a deal to sella nuclear bomb to the Egyptians. That’s not great news for Israel, which isn’t good news for the rest of us. Nasty business nuclear war.
Look, I’m not proud of what my father has done, but I told you, I haven’t seen or heard from him in eighteen years.
We believe he’s working for this man. He points to a man seated next to the Professor. He’s dre in an expensive linen suit but his face is mostly covered the Professor’s arm.
I can’t help you. She disappears back under the car. Solo pulls her back ou again.
But I bet you know someone who can. An old friend, a relative?  Gaby thinks about it, shakes her head.
I can't...
If you'll agree to help us, I can have you on the other side of the Wall tonight.
You do understand that I could be tortured and imprisoned just for listening to you?
I’m offering you a new life. Freedom from all of that.
How do I know you are who you say you are? How do I know that anything you’ve told me is true? He looks her directly in the eyes.
I know this is sudden. I wish there was more time. But that’s how urgent the situation is. I will protect you and I will get you over that wall. I just need you to...
Trust you?
Trust me. And she almost does. Almost but...
Why? Because you’re handsome and have a nice smile?
Shall I make this easier? He reveals the machine gun under his jacket. SOLO (CONT’D) You're now my prisoner, you don’t have a choice.
That does make it easier.
I have a driver waiting for us outside.

Solo heads out the door and slows abruptly. He notices th Ernst’s car is not quite in the same place, and it’s hard see Ernst. He’s at a strange angle, Solo doesn’t like thi he drops down quickly as a bullet whistles past his ear. He rolls back into the shop.
(afraid) What’s going on? Who just shot at us?
I need the keys to that thing.
What have you done?
The Russians are after your father too. It’s us or them. Like I said, you don’t have a choice. Beat, as her mind clearly shifts.
I’m the only person who drives this car.

The shooter moves closer to get a better angle on the entrance to the garage. Meet ILYA KURYAKIN, Russian, he’s his early 30’s and radiates a rare combination of physica power and intelligence. However in contrast, his choice of clothing is distinctly odd. He wears a suit, but it’s a conspicuously bold color and shirt and tie have striking patterns which are completely mismatched. On anyone else, this get-up would look clowni but Kuryakin manages to make it look cool. As he’s crossing the street, Gaby’s car roars out. Kuryak snaps his gun up to take aim, but instead of turning down street, Gaby drives up on the sidewalk to be shielded by parked vehicles. Kuryakin lowers his gun, calmly walks back to his car, cl in, and roars after them.

Gaby’s car screeches around the corner, scattering pedestrians. Other cars are forced to swerve out of the w In the car, Gaby is clearly in her element. Her confidenc returns as she focuses on driving which she does with ext ordinary skill. Kuryakin follows, relentless.
INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Gaby slams on the brakes.
What are you doing?
This guy isn’t going to give up.
I am aware of that, but what are you doing? She slams the car into reverse and tightens her safety be
Hold on tight. This car is tougher than it looks. She hits the gas.
INT. KURYAKIN’S CAR - DAY He rounds the corner to find Gaby looking over her should reversing straight at him at forty miles an hour. Kuryaki has no time to dodge.
EXT. EAST BERLIN STREETS —- DAY CRASH. There is an enormous smash as both cars come to a halt. However, Gaby’s car is relatively undamaged. She te away.
INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Gaby turns to a shaken Solo.
You okay?
Where did you learn to drive like this?
What’s the point in fixing cars if you can’t drive them?

EXT. EAST BERLIN STREETS —- DAY Kuryakin coolly climbs out of the wreckage of his car, an surveys all the other cars that have stopped to look at t incident. He eventually sees one at the back, it looks fa He walks up to the DRIVER.
(in German) I saw the whole thing, that woman's a lunatic! Kuryakin waves his gun at him with a gesture that says “t is my car now” and the journey continues.

INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY She continues to drive fast, avoiding traffic, but eventu she finds herself behind a rubbish truck, picking up tras Another car is close behind her, she’s stuck. She calmly looks around.
We can’t stay here.

Really? You’re very observant. She glances at a parallel road a block over, searching fo another way out. Suddenly, a car tears down the parallel road. We only see it for a flash, but we know it’s Kuryak Solo and Gaby look at each other.
He couldn’t have seen us? Pause. We hear a screech of tires.

Shall we get out of here? Kuryakin’s car tears back and stops. How could he possibl have seen them? Within a second, he is firing shots from pistol just inches away from their target. Gaby doesn’t hang around. Again she puts the car in rever forcing the car behind her back. This gives her enough ro to mount the curb, knocking the TRASH COLLECTORS out of t way. She’s off again.
INT. KURYAKIN’S CAR - DAY Kuryakin steers with one hand, and shoots with the other. He’s calmer than a coma.
INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo shoots back. Gaby downshifts.
That man can drive. Can’t you shoot better than that?  11.
You concentrate on the road. She makes a hard left into an alley. Solo is thrown to one side and drops his gun on the floor
Kuryakin overshoots.
INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo picks up his gun.
Better? Suddenly, her expression changes.

Oh no! Up ahead is a sharp drop as a steep stone pedestrian staircase leads down to the road below. Solo looks behind them. Kuryakin is catching up again. Si are approaching behind him. Gaby is slowing down. Solo stays cool.
We can make it. Gaby is shaking her head. Solo starts to climb into the b seat.
What are you doing?
We need more weight in the back.
I can't...  12.
You can. You don’t, we’re both dead... Trust me... Now put your foot down. Gaby looks at him, hits the gas, and they’re airborne.

Amazingly, the car lands on the steps, the back flies up, it doesn't flip. Instead, it carries on down the steps, reaching the bottom with a crunch. Kuryakin stops his car at the top of the steps. He climbs of his car and watches them speed away. INT. GABY’S CAR - DAY Solo breathes a sigh of relief.
I'm impressed. You alright?
That’s a stupid question.
Shall I drive now?
You’re okay, pal. Just stay where you are. More sirens. Flashing lights in the distance.
In there. He points to a multi-story parking structure.
Gaby parks her car. INT. CAR — DAY Solo and Gaby sit, tensely listening to the sirens go by. Gradually, the sound fades into the distance.  13.
Still going over the Wall tonight?
Follow me. He climbs out of the car.
As Solo and Gaby head for the exit, a car turns into the structure. Solo pulls Gaby down behind a car. As the vehicle passes, they see that it’s Kuryakin.
Who is this guy? He pulls her through the back-door.
As he and Gaby hurry down the alleyway, Solo looks back t see Kuryakin, looking down at him from the second floor o the parking structure. Solo pulls Gaby around the corner and breaks into a run.
Solo and Gaby run. And run. And run.
Surrounded by industrial warehouses. Solo and Gaby crouch hidden in the shadows of one of the warehouses. They are of breath and Gaby looks spent.

We haven’t lost him, have we? Solo puts a finger to his lips. A long beat. Sure enough, Kuryakin appears between the buildings, coming towards th A distant rumble grows louder. A train trundles along the tracks moving between them and Kuryakin.

Come on.  14. He pulls Gaby up, and they run towards the train. Solo manages to open one of the doors and push Gaby in. On the other side, Kuryakin scans the night as the end of train passes gradually, revealing the warehouses that wer hidden behind it. It appears that Kuryakin is going to let the train pass. the last minute, he runs to catch up with the final carri and jumps onboard.
Solo has been watching from the window. He pulls his head
Did he get on?
Let’s move.
This is your idea of going over the Wall? He leads her towards the front of the train. As they head along the passageway, the CONDUCTOR exits a compartment.
(in German) Tickets please. He looks slightly suspicious at their dishevelled state.

Two tickets for the Center please. He pays the Conductor, who takes forever to give them cha As they continue down the passageway, Kuryakin appears at other end. They hurry down the train. Finally, they reach the hallway outside the driver's compartment. They can go no further. Solo opens the exterior door, but the train is travelling fast to jump off. He looks ahead and sees the Berlin Wall approaching.  15. SOLO (CONT’D) The train has to slow down to make the turn when it reaches the Wall. That's when we jump. Sirens and flashing lights. Solo looks out again. There a now two cop cars driving alongside the train. Here comes Kuryakin. Solo ducks around the corner, just a volley of silenced machine gun fire thuds into the wall n to his head. Gaby is crouched down, covering her head, body shaking.
(yells down the corridor) You have no place to go, Mr. Solo. Give yourself up. There’s no reason for the girl to die.
(to himself) He knows my name???? Solo knows he’s right unless... He tries the Driver’s door. Locked. Solo shoots the lock, barges the door open.
Solo sticks his gun in the DRIVER'S face. He’s a big, str fellow.
(in German) Faster.
We won’t make the turn. The train will crash into... He gestures to the approaching Berlin Wall.
Faster. The Driver doesn’t move, but his eyes give him away, flic to the accelerator handle.

Thank you.  16. Solo jams the accelerator forward. At that moment, the Dr grabs for the gun. They grapple as the Wall approaches. Suddenly, Kuryakin is in the cabin, his gun in Solo’s fac He squeezes the trigger as...
The train jumps the tracks and smashes through the Wall.
Solo, Kuryakin, and the Driver are tossed around as the f of the train rolls over.
There is a massive hole in the Wall. More than half the length of the train has gone through it, and is now in th West. The front carriage is on its side.
Solo swims back into consciousness. The Driver lies groan next to him. Solo crawls into the passageway. He sees the girl, and he a groan, she’s semi-conscious.

Gaby?!...Can you hear me? Her eyes open. SOLO (CONT’D) You're going to be alright. You’re safe now. We hear the sound of sirens as West German POLICE turn up Kuryakin is stuck in the wreckage, and can’t free himself easily, he can see his targets disappearing as he attempt pull himself out.  17.
Solo watches as a DOCTOR examines Gaby. She winces as he touches her bruised ribs.
(to himself) Welcome to freedom. There’s a knock on the door and SANDERS enters. He’s an effete little man with an air of great cunning and intelligence about him. He’s also Solo’s boss.
Well done Solo. Solo stares at him for a long beat.
Why don’t we step outside.
Sanders puts the kettle on.
Well, it appears the Russians are as anxious as we are to find Professor Teller.
I’ve had enough.

What is your secret? (beat) You know there’s no one in the history of the Agency with a higher success rate when it comes to recruiting and running female assets. You’re a bit of a legend. A long pause. Solo stares at Sanders.
You heard what I said.
You need a break.  18.
No, I have had enough. Twelve years of playing your little games. I’m done.
You seem to be forgetting something... You’re on thin ice Solo, and there are things, unpleasant things, lurking under it.
Threatening me with a prison cell has lost its traction Sanders. Put me away, it’s better for everyone's health.
Pull yourself together Solo. Solo suddenly grabs him by the throat and pins him agains the wall.
This won’t mean much to you, but she trusted me.
Look Solo, she’s going to be okay. There's a beat, Solo releases his grip.
I tell you what, let’s meet again tomorrow, we’ll talk about it sensibly.
An EGYPTIAN OFFICER is running outside the barracks, he l fit and has an expression like he means it. We become awa of a man running up behind him. This is ALEXANDER SKORPIO he’s dressed to run.
Colonel. I heard you were an early bird. The Egyptian acknowledges him, but continues running.  19.
I like the sand before the sun beats it.
I hope I am not bothering you?
Not in the least, you and the Professor have done Egypt a great service... But I thought you had left already, Mr... “Smith.”
I’m back for the day. A couple of loose ends I needed to tie up. By way, my name is Alex...
No. Please. Let’s stick to protocol.
Oh, I’m confident you can be trusted Colonel. I’m Alexander Skorpios.
Good to meet you, Mr. Skorpios.

You're quite a legend in the camp, Colonel, winner of the army triathlon six years in a row. (beat) Do you mind if I train with you today? I am an amateur athlete myself and this will be my last opportunity, since our business is concluded.
You’re welcome to, but I warn you, this is not a short work out.
Two hours every morning. A twelve mile run, followed by a two mile swim, and a cool down in the gym. Your routine is famous. I’1l drop out as soon as you pull away.  20.
Very good then.
An hour later. Alexander has clearly impressed the Colone COLONEL (CONT’D) You are doing very well, Mr. Skorpios.
I am inspired by my company.
We can see the Colonel is a tad concerned by the determination and ability of this man. They have reached sea.
So, the sea. I go round the buoy, then back again.
I am ready.

An hour later. Alexander is clearly in front and showing signs of fatigue, the Colonel on the other hand is now tr to keep up... EXT. EGYPTIAN BEACH —- MORNING Alexander is waiting on the beach... jogging on the spot. Colonel pulls himself out of the water, he’s desperately trying to not look knackered.
Where did you learn to swim like that?
My father taught me that true physical strength lies not in the body, but in the mind. If you chew bitter for long enough, eventually it turns sweet. The gym?  21.
Alexander is on the bench with a bar over him...
Could you spot me? Alexander thumps out ten reps of a very heavy weight.
Your turn.
That weight is too much.
It’s all in your mind, Colonel.
The Colonel is on the bench, under a weight that he has t struggle with. Alexander stands over him, almost mockingl
Push push, that’s the spirit Colonel, now we're getting somewhere. Let’s see how strong you really are. At which point, Alexander releases the weight and the Col takes the strain.
That's it. Now tell me, how long have you been a spy? The Colonel is about to explode with the weight that’s ov him.
Take the weight off me. I don’t know what you’re talking about.
You're just not trying hard enough. Who are you working for, the Americans, or the Russians? The Colonel can’t take the weight for much longer.
Please...!  22.
Tell me what I want to know, and I can help you.
The Americans... and the Russians.
Thank you Colonel. Alexander reaches down and takes hold of the bar.
How did you know?
You and your government have no idea who you're dealing with Colonel. With almost superhuman strength, he raises the bar before slams it down.
A beautiful sunny day. Solo is walking with Sanders through public gardens.
How’s the girl? Is she going to be helpful? He walks into a public restroom, gesturing that Solo shou follow.
Sanders checks the cubicles.
I think so...
You’1l have to do better than that.
There’s an old friend and colleague of her father’s, a Rudolph Von Trulsch, endearingly known as “Uncle Rudi.” Lives in Greece, works for a big shipping company. (MORE )
She's sure if anybody will be in touch with her father, he’s the man. Sanders is relieving himself.
Rudi Von Trulsch. I think I have a file on him somewhere. Name of the shipping company?
Triton.
Even more interesting, rumor has it they smuggled Nazi gold to South America after the war. Can she be trusted?
That’s your department now sir, I got you the girl and I got you a name. Now I’m done.
No Solo, you'll be done when I tell you you're done.

I don’t think you understand. I am over it, for about a thousand reasons, not least of which, I am losing whatever advantage I had over these people. That lunatic Russian android they put on me yesterday isn’t like men I have come up against before. He was a relentless Olympian. That was the closest I have come to termination in the last ten years. It wasn’t me that saved me, it was a banana skin here and a rabbit foot there. In other words, luck. You want to send me back to the cell, send me. I’11 go. But I am done here. A MAN wearing a hat enters, shutting Sanders up. Solo looks over his shoulder as the Man raises his head, Kuryakin. They both look as surprised as the other about unlikely meeting.  24. Without another word, they spring into action. They attem to draw their guns, but there isn’t enough space to use t A serious amount of hand-to-hand combat takes place, destroying the lavatory. It ends with Kuryakin putting a choke hold around Solo’s neck. Solo looks up for help from Sanders, he doesn’t have much time. His boss calmly washes his hands as he gasps his la breath. Solo spots an owl-like man entering the room. This is Kuryakin’s boss, OLEG. He has the eccentric appearance of chess grandmaster. He barks an order at Kuryakin.

Let him go Ilya. You don’t want to kill your partner on the first day. Kuryakin’s hold gradually relaxes, both men look shocked this information. Solo looks up at his boss, who throws a the paper towel.
That's what I was about to explain Solo, but as usual you jumped the gun. We were going to meet them in the cafe outside. Nature’s needs clearly got the better of their agent as he did of you.
Oleg sips a cup of tea.
We don’t know yet who is behind this but we both agree, not that Sanders and I have ever talked before... He and Sanders chuckle.
...-that it’s unacceptable to both our nations to have a third party manufacturing and selling nuclear weapons to the highest bidder. Sanders nods.  25.
Our mutual interests dictate that we should work together. Unofficially and off-the-books, of course, if the politicians knew about this...
(to Sanders) You're forgetting something.
Excuse us for a second. Solo come with me. Sanders stands and Solo follows.

I am not asking you to find the President's missing sticky book, it’s nuclear war we're talking about!... If that’s not enough, and prison isn’t, then how about secret account number 583937994? Your retirement policy. A tidy little sum from your noir racketeering days... That account is now frozen, and I am the only man who can make it thaw, but first, you’re going to go to work.
That man sitting there is the enemy! He killed your top agent in East Berlin not twenty-four hours ago, and spent the majority of yesterday trying very hard to kill me...

Well, you’1l be in safe hands then. You yourself reported on how capable he was. There is no choice in this Solo. Finish the job and then, and only then, are you done. Now, we have twenty-four hours to get ready then you head to Greece with the Russian and the girl, as a team. Solo, looks over to Kuryakin. They just stare at each oth

head_text.subj: BETWEEN CIA CINE ROOM AND KGB CINE ROOM AS FOLLO

text: Lights off, a Super 8 film fills us in: Images of a child soldier getting a medal. A young man swimming in the Olympics. Another image pops up of him firing a gun at a target with deadly accuracy.

Kuryakin’s father was killed by the Nazis at the siege of Leningrad. The day he got the news, our boy joined the army. He was fourteen. Killed so many Germans he was given the nickname “The Leningrad Plague.” The KGB recruited him after the war and spent years refining him. His one flaw appears to be his temper. But make no mistake, he’s their top agent.
Oleg clicks his finger and the lights are off, and Oleg w in front of the film projected onto a wall. Now it’s Solo turn.

Solo was a sergeant in the Marines during the war. He was awarded the Military Cross for bravery. He was stationed in Berlin after the war, where he became involved in multiple criminal activities, mostly dealing in black-market goods. He speaks many languages, and he’s highly cultured for all the wrong reasons. He has a a broad knowledge of art, wine, antiques, only in order to know it’s black market value. He was facing a fifteen year prison sentence for his crimes, but the CIA recognized his talent and offered to withhold his sentence, as long as he worked for them. Since then, he has been involved in some of their most important and dangerous clandestine operations. He has consistently bested our top operatives. (MORE )
He’s not predictable. He’s not a product of the system. Kuryakin nods. Sanders paces in front of Solo.

Your main mission is to prevent the delivery of the bomb. That is the first priority. However, you have a second obligation. Professor Teller’s research represents the next generation of nuclear weapons technology. It’s way ahead of anything we or the Russians have currently, and clearly he’s succeeded in putting it into practice. That research will be on a disk. We must have that disk and above all else, it must not fall into the hands of the Russians. Oleg lies on a sofa while Kuryakin paces.
...it is essential that we get it and not the Americans. Once you have completed your main mission... Sanders stops pacing.
You are to use any means... Oleg gets off the sofa.
..-mecessary to secure it. Do I make... Sanders stares at Solo. 27.
..-myself clear?
Gaby sits opposite Solo, who passes her a cup of tea. She looking much better.
I kept my end of the deal, and I almost died for it. And now you want me to come to Greece?
Look we don’t have much time, and I need access to Uncle Rudi. If anybody knows where your father is, it’s him, and if there’s one person he’ll tell, it’s you.
I can’t do this. I don’t know this world, you’re asking me to be something I am not.

Trust me. All I need you to be is yourself. I’11l guide you through it, this is what I do. Look at it as a holiday. You can see the sights, get a tan. And I promise there'll be no danger. She's melting.
Promise?
Promise. The chemistry between them is undeniable, but Solo’s all business. SOLO (CONT’D) Now, you need some clothes. Let’s go shopping.  29.
A nice mid-range place that sells sensible clothes. Solo watches as Gaby looks at dresses. He spots an elegant black dress.
This one isn’t bad. He shows Gaby the dress. She shakes her head.
Black is for funerals. She turns to look at another dress. A troubled look passe over Solo’s face. He’s all too aware that Gaby’s wellbein again his responsibility.
So Russia and America have become friends over this issue have they?
Well, friends might be an overstatement... But as coincidence would have it, you do already know the man we have to partner with.
Know him? How can I know him? At which point, Solo spots Kuryakin. As usual, he’s dress in an outlandishly colorful and mismatched get-up, which somehow manages to make cool.
(to Kuryakin) You're early.
We're in a hurry.
Wait just a second. Isn’t that the man...?
Yes, it is. I told you, you know him.
You've got to be kidding.  30.
It’s going to be fine. Kuryakin smiles and takes her hand.
Ilya Kuryakin. You are quite a driver young lady, I like that ina woman.
I feel sick. Make it stop.
That’s perfectly normal, you'll get used to the feeling. He sees the dress.
Did you pick this dress? Looking at Solo. KURYAKIN (CONT’D) There is no way my woman is wearing this dress.
What do you mean “my woman?” Solo, what does he mean?
I think you should leave this department to me, no offense but...
My fiancee would never wear this.
Fiancee? They ignore her.
Really, now you're a Russian fashion expert? And that suit is your qualification?
So you’re an expert on what a Russian architect looks like, Cowboy?  31.
I’m not doing this. She storms out of the shop. Solo looks sarcastically at I
Good work.
Your job was to prepare her.
Your job was to give me time.
It’s a beautiful evening. Gaby paces in front of a founta while Solo talks.

He’s an architect designing a new resort for heroes of the Soviet Union by the Black Sea. The Minister has a weakness for classical architecture so he’s been sent to Greece to study it. He’s managed to get a visa for his fiancee.
(in horror) Me?!
It’s the perfect cover. Since Uncle Rudi lives in Athens, it’s only natural that you would pay hima visit to tell him the good news, and ask him about your father.
Now you want me to be an actress?
It’s easier than it seems, I’11l coach you through it. Gaby shakes her head.
This is insane.  32.
You can do it Gaby, I'll admit it’s a challenge, but I know you can handle it. She considers, but again she’s melting.
I can’t believe I’m doing this. What will you be doing while I’m playing the Russian bride?
I'll be playing an executive for American oil, on a business trip to check out Triton shipping, Rudi’s employer.
